channel.title: Where do you start?
channel.description:
For the "programmers" out there, if you were to remake RS for make a game from scratch where would you start?
You already have your brainstorming/ideas compiled and you open up your IDE of choice, select new project, enter in your project name etc etc. [b]Whats the first class/file you make and WHY?[/b] :)
Lets see where this goes. I am just curious to see how other people function when they first initially start a project.

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

s1gma:

u must do things the agile way

Agile isn’t a method, it’s a methodology. It’s a set of optional, core principles you base the foundation of a team on, not a means of creating software. I find a few of the principles to be fundamental, one of them being open to adapting and changing the way you are currently developing software (which includes ignoring parts of the Agile manifesto that do not apply to your particular team). As to that, I am very much open to changing the way I do things. I consider that the “Agile-way”.

Read full topic

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

sini:

know whats the funny thing, runescape is pretty much duct taped together code. jagex paid some MASSIVE (and still pays) tech debt. runescape doesnt really have any concrete rules, like expectations for how you’d follow things to work because theres a disassociation with how menu actions and actions are processed. its bloody retarded sometimes.

It’s all legacy code.

Read full topic

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

probably with the map system (tiles or however you decide to do it), then add things like clipping, interactable objects, entity, interaction system, etc… you’ll throw in progress saving somewhere along the way since it doesn’t get that complex and you’ll need it anyways.

Read full topic

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I sometimes start at the platform level (algorithms, db, etc) but usually go straight into the visual stuff as a fast prototype. Whatever I do, I usually end up throwing it away after a few weeks, and that gives me a better idea of how to architect everything and start again from scratch. It also helps me get over the one aspect that interests me the most about the project (e.g., super efficient multiplayer handling, cool terrain generator, etc), then I can build the thing properly without getting distracted and going on a tangent.

I don’t think making a big plan is a great way to build software, especially if you don’t deviate from it. I like doing it because it makes it easier to track progress and I find it more motivational, but often find myself going down a fundamentally flawed route just because it was the original plan.

Read full topic

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

I don’t need any “help”, all I am looking for is an insight on the logic for other “programmers” out there and how they break down a huge project into different factors and specifically where they PREFER/LIKE to start.

I think you’re looking for a process, when one doesn’t really exist. Every program is too different from another to have some sort of general approach that works for everything. From my experience, starting is not the important part. If you plan out an entire application from the beginning, you’re basically just wasting time. Software always changes during development; it’s impossible to plan for all of it to begin with. There are two extremes. You either start with no planning or start with trying to plan every minute detail. Programmers fall between these two extremes. You can build effective software on both ends of the spectrum. I think it comes to a question of practicality more than preparedness. I think there should be a careful balance between how much time you prepare to write code and how much you spend writing and testing it. What this balance is depends on the programmer and it’s something you should experiment to find out. It really does not have to do with starting a project, though. Every time you want to add a new feature to an application or fix a bug involves the same thought process as starting an entirely new application.

Read full topic

item.title: Where do you start?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

I don’t need any “help”, all I am looking for is an insight on the logic for other “programmers” out there and how they break down a huge project into different factors and specifically where they PREFER/LIKE to start.

Look into design heuristics, system architectures and maybe design patterns.
Once you understand the logic behind that, the logic behind creating your application becomes clear. The approch you take it totally unique to yourself. If I was to make a calculator and somebody else was to make one too, it’ll be completly different. They could both be top quality however it’s simply down to other developers to which they would prefer.

Where you start in creating an application is totally up to you. I usually do the easy stuff first, then do the hard stuff

Read full topic
